segments.content: The segment discusses the need for continuous health care interventions and occupational health and safety policies to protect the health and productivity of the economically active population due to scarce resources and demographic changes, emphasizing the importance of defining health benefits according to quality of life and productivity-adjusted life years (PALYs) to make critical decisions based on evidence from clinical trials, observational studies, and productivity consequences.

The QALY evaluation function is characterized by the combination of productivity independence, health independence, time invariance at common health and full productivity, and productivity invariance at full health and common time, and can be interpreted as an effect measure for economic evaluation of healthcare or working environment interventions, with the generalized PALY evaluation function being evaluated by aggregating individual PALYs in society, submitted first to a continuous function (v), and the affine PALY evaluation function being evaluated by aggregating individual PALYs in society, submitted first to an affine and non-decreasing function, both subject to the productivity invariance at full health and common time axiom.

The segment discusses evaluating distributions using the productivity-and-quality-adjusted life years (PQALY) function, which considers natural compromises between various evaluation functions by strengthening the time and productivity independence axioms, resulting in the formally characterized PQALY evaluation function (TICHP and PICHT).

segments.content: A social planner may choose the QALY-PQALY evaluation function, which considers health effects and productivity effects multiplicatively, while also considering the time invariance at common health and productivity (TICHP) or full health and productivity (TIFHP) to evaluate distributions, yielding alternative evaluation functions like QALY-PALY and HPYE, each with their own specific weight functions and implications for the evaluation of interventions.

the original text and supporting examples for a detailed understanding of the methodology and its implications for utilizing evaluation functions and axioms in empirical applications, particularly in economic evaluations of health care or working environment interventions, where the focus is on both health and productivity effects, and the choice of evaluation function is guided by the satisfaction of the chosen axioms, ultimately leading to the adoption of the QALY-PALY approach when a majority consensus on indifference between adding productivity to one type or another is observed.

When considering preferences and a preference hierarchy (PHEF) represented by a function f i that maps inputs (a, p, t) to outputs (t * i), it is possible to assume that p i captures the probability to succeed in life for individual i, rather than assuming productivity ranges from 0 to 1, and the evaluation function ϕ(a, p, t) can be defined as w(a, p) * t, where 0 ≤ w(a, p) ≤ w(a *, p) ≤ w(a *, 1) = 1, and 0 ≤ w(a, p) ≤ w(a, 1) ≤ w(a *, 1) = 1 for each (a, p) in A × [0, 1]. This allows for a more nuanced representation of preferences and their consequences in the context of a strictly increasing hierarchy (g).
